thread.title: Severe storm cuts power to 40,000 homes across Sydney, Central Coast
thread.title_full: Severe storm cuts power to 40,000 homes across Sydney, Central Coast

author: Riley Stuart
title: Severe storm cuts power to 40,000 homes across Sydney, Central Coast
text:
Map: Sydney 2000 
A powerful storm that blitzed through Sydney this afternoon before moving north-east has left at least 40,000 homes without power, with the Central Coast most affected. 
The storm dumped rain and hail across parts of western Sydney earlier this afternoon, before impacting the Greater Sydney area, with the NSW SES saying the city escaped relatively unscathed. 
"Because the storm moved quickly we didn't see too much damage," NSW SES spokesman Phil Campbell said. 
Ausgrid said power was cut to around 700 customers around Sydney, in parts of St Ives and North Turramurra on Sydney's upper north shore, but it was the Central Coast that is worst affected. 
"There's now around 40,000 homes and businesses that are without power, mainly across the central coast area," Ausgrid's Anthony O'Brian said. External Link: Lightning map around Sydney 
"It's a result of that large lightening storm that came through so quickly this afternoon." 
Mr O'Brien said the lightning strikes caused damage to infrastructure, and crews were working to fix the problem. 
Earlier in Sydney winds of up to 93 kilometres per hour winds were recorded at Horsley Park in Sydney's west, and hail battered parts of Penrith. 
A severe thunderstorm warning was still in place for areas around Gosford and Wyong, with Newcastle, Wollongong, Bowral, Orange, Mudgee, Bathurst and Katoomba also affected. 
"The storms have now moved across to the Lower Hunter and the Central Coast," the BOM's Rob Taggart said.
